posts.content:
I’ve spent a lot of time working with clinical trial data, and sometimes that means working with values that are not, eh, clean.One larger issue I’ve had to resolve over and over again has been inprecise dates.I’ve incorporated a few functions into an experimental package I’ve been working on: dirtyr.I’m still working out some things and it, so hopefully this post is still accurate by the time I’m happy with a first real release.These functions aren’t necessarily written for optimization.They work, though.
Let’s walk through working on some bad dates that we could encounter.
# devtools::install_github("jmbarbone/dirtyr")library(dirtyr)We’ll start with creating some bad data.
dates <- c("01 JAN 1996", "Feb 2010", "2019")Normal methods won’t get us where we need to go.We’ll get date
as.Date(dates, format = "%d %B %Y")[1] "1996-01-01" NA NA lubridate::dmy(dates)Warning: 2 failed to parse.[1] "1996-01-01" NA NA unknown_date(dates, format = "dmy")[1] "1996-01-01" "2010-02-01" "2019-01-01"unknown_date(dates, format = "dmy", "latest")[1] "1996-01-01" "2010-02-28" "2019-12-31"These date functions are written in base.lubridate is a fantastic package but I wanted to avoid dependencies.These also have nowhere near the same scope as lubridate.
posts.summary: I’ve spent a lot of time working with clinical trial data, and sometimes that means working with values that are not, eh, clean.One larger issue I’ve had to resolve over and over again has been inprecise dates.I’ve incorporated a few functions into an experimental package I’ve been working on: dirtyr.I’m still working out some things and it, so hopefully this post is still accurate by the time I’m happy with a first real release.
posts.title: Dirty Dates
